content.question: Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A block of mass <math alttext="m"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is moving with speed <math alttext="v"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> along a horizontal surface when it collides with a uniform rod of mass <math alttext="2 m"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and length <math alttext="L"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> attached at one end to a pivot. The surface and pivot have negligible friction. The rod is vertical when the block collides with the end of the rod. The block sticks to the rod, and the block-rod system rotates so that the end of the rod reaches a height <math alttext="h"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown above. The total rotational inertia of the rod about the pivot is <math alttext="2 m, times L squared, over 3"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mi>m</mi><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>/</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Express answers in parts (a), (b), and (c) in terms of <math alttext="m"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="L"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="v"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants as appropriate. (a) Derive an expression for the angular speed <math alttext="omega"><mstyle><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the block-rod system immediately after the collision.

The surface and pivot have negligible friction. The rod is vertical when the block collides with the end of the rod. The block sticks to the rod, and the block-rod system rotates so that the end of the rod reaches a height <math alttext="h"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown above. The total rotational inertia of the rod about the pivot is <math alttext="2 m, times L squared, over 3"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mi>m</mi><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>/</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Express answers in parts (a), (b), and (c) in terms of <math alttext="m"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="L"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="v"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants as appropriate. (a) Derive an expression for the angular speed <math alttext="omega"><mstyle><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the block-rod system immediately after the collision.

(b) Show that the change in height <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the bottom of the rod can be given by the equation <math alttext="h equals the fraction 3 v squared over 20 g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn><msup><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>20</mn><mi>g</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(c) Derive an expression for the mechanical energy dissipated during the collision.

Student use the setup to determine an experimental value for the acceleration due to gravity <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The students use a block of mass <math alttext="500 grams" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and a rod of mass <math alttext="1.0 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and length <math alttext="1.0 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. For each trial, the rod is set in its vertical position, and the block is launched toward it. The speed of the block is varied for each trial, and the height <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured. The data are shown in the chart below. <math alttext="v, in meters per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi><mtext>(m/s)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="1.5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="2.5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="h, in meters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mtext>(m)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="0.015" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.015</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="0.034" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>0.034</mn></mrow></math> <math alttext="0.060" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>0.060</mn></mrow></math> <math alttext="0.096" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>0.096</mn></mrow></math> <math alttext="0.138" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>0.138</mn></mrow></math> (d) Which quantities should be graphed on the vertical and horizontal axes to yield a straight line whose slope could be used to calculate a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Use the remaining rows in the table above, as needed, to record any quantities that you indicated that are not given.

(e) Plot the experimental data for the quantities indicated in part <math alttext="d"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>d</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> on the graph below. Clearly scale and label all axes including units, if appropriate. Draw a straight line that best represents the data.
(f) Using your straight line, determine an experimental value for <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(g) A new block of mass <math alttext="m"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is used. This block is made of a material that makes an elastic collision with the rod when the block and rod collide. Will the height <math alttext="h"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> increase, decrease, or stay the same? ____ Increase ____ Decrease ____ Stay the same Justify your answer.
